output.conclusion: This course provided a foundational understanding of mathematical modeling. You are now equipped to explore more advanced techniques and apply these models to real-world problems.
output.introduction: Welcome to Mathematical Modeling! This course will introduce you to the basics of creating and using mathematical models to understand and predict real-world phenomena. No prior advanced math knowledge is required.

chapters.description: An introduction to the concept of mathematical modeling, its purpose, and its applications in various fields.
Overview of different types of mathematical models (e.g., linear, exponential, discrete, continuous).
Step-by-step guide to the mathematical modeling process: problem definition, model formulation, solution, validation, and interpretation.
Understanding the role of variables (dependent and independent) and parameters in a mathematical model.
Importance of consistent units and dimensional analysis in model formulation.
Discussing the need for assumptions and simplifications in building a tractable model.
Review of linear equations and their properties. Focus on slope-intercept form.
Visual representation of linear equations and their interpretation.
Examples of using linear models to represent real-world relationships (e.g., cost functions, distance-time problems).
Introduction to exponential functions and their properties.
Modeling growth and decay processes using exponential functions (e.g., population growth, radioactive decay).
Real-world examples of exponential models (e.g., compound interest, drug metabolism).
Understanding the difference between discrete and continuous models and when to use each.
Introduction to difference equations as a tool for discrete modeling.
Applications of discrete models (e.g., population dynamics, financial models).
Techniques for validating a mathematical model (e.g., comparing model predictions with real-world data).
Assessing the sensitivity of model outputs to changes in input parameters.
Understanding the limitations of mathematical models and the importance of critical evaluation.
